text: love this is chef john from food wishes
comm did lobster Newburg that's right
not only is this recipe fast and
delicious it's also the most famous
anagram in culinary history as this was
invented by a man named Ben Wenberg who
showed it to a friend of his who owned a
restaurant and he put it on the menu
where became very popular until they had
a big argument at which point the
restaurant owner just to screw with this
guy's head rearrange the letters in the
name and lobster Weinberg became lobster
Newburg and if you've ever worked in a
restaurant or known restaurant owners
you're probably thinking yep
that sounds about right but of course
none of that really matters all we care
about is how amazing this is so let me
show you how to put this together and of
course it's going to require some
Lobster and I'm going to use lobster
tails for this so I have four four ounce
tails so all we need to do at this point
is take a sharp knife and split these
lobster tails in half and while the
shell feels kind of hard it actually is
pretty easy to cut just put your knife
right in the center like this cut
straight down through and then we'll
just turn it and finish the cut and
that's pretty much it and by the way the
original was done with whole lobsters so
the tails do make this a little more
user-friendly and sure they're a little
pricey but every once in a while you do
see them on sale and while I generally
don't recommend buying your food at
stores that also sell tires and socks
every once in a while those big-box
stores sometimes have great deals on
this kind of thing so keep your antenna
up and then once we have those split
we're going to cook those in a little
bit of clarified butter but before we do
I do want to give them a little bit of
salt and by a little bit I mean a
generous amount at which point we're
going to transfer those into a pan
that's been set over medium-high heat
with a little bit of clarified butter in
the pan and we'll place those lobster
tails in cut side down and we're only
going to cook them on that side for
about two minutes okay we're not trying
to brown these we just want to barely
cook them through so like I said we'll
go about two minutes on this side and
we'll go ahead and flip them over and
give another minute or two on the shell
side and quite often in this recipe
it'll say just steamed the lobster which
works but using this technique we're
infusing that clarified butter in the
pan with a ton of extra lobster flavor
so I do like this method better than
steaming and once those have been cooked
for a couple minutes on each side we'll
go ahead and remove those to a plate to
cool and as soon as we've done that I
want you to go ahead and drizzle in a
couple tablespoons of sherry or cognac
or brandy or something like that into
the pan which of course is still pretty
hot
don't walk away because all we're going
to do is cook this for about one minute
until it basically reduces in half and
it does not have to be exact just let it
go until it looks like about half is
evaporated away and then we'll simply
turn off the heat and just reserve that
pan as is while we move on to prop the
rest of the ingredients which is pretty
easy all we need to do is wait for those
lobster tails to get cool enough to
handle and you're simply going to pull
out the meat which is going to come out
very very easily and by the way if we
have any Lobster experts in the audience
might Al's had some like bluish blackish
coloration along the bottom of the shell
and near the tail fin which I don't
think is dangerous in any way I just
didn't like how it looks what causes
that anyway we're going to pull that
meat out of the tails and of course be
careful don't lose any of those precious
juices so make sure you do this over a
plate or a bowl and then once you've
liberated that meat we're going to go
ahead and give it a rough chop not too
small maybe half inch pieces you know
the drill pick a size and stick with it
so now withstanding a few blue and black
spots that's looking pretty good
and then as I just mentioned we're of
course going to transfer those
accumulated juices back into our pan and
at that point we can move on to the last
of the sauce ingredients so in a bowl we
have some heavy cream to which we're
going to add two egg yolks
we're also going to add some cayenne
pepper a little more than just a little
and then last but not least a little bit
of freshly grated nutmeg and we'll
officially call that a pinch on the
ingredient list but of course there was
no pinching involved since I always want
you to grate this fresh so a very very
simple sauce just a few ingredients and
then we'll simply take a whisk and mix
this up and once that's mixed up we are
ready for final assembly and do not move
on to these last steps until you're
ready to eat because this dish comes
together very very quickly but when we
are ready let's go ahead and dump our
cream mixture into the pan which as you
remember contains our lobster infused
butter and that little bit of sherry
reduction and please keep in mind the
heats been off all this time so we'll
dump in our cream mixture we'll whisk
that in and then we're going to do two
things we're going to set our heat
between medium low and medium so just a
notch above medium low and we'll also
switch to a spatula which allows me to
stir and scrape the bottom of the pan
and all we're going to do is heat this
mixture stirring constantly until it's
slightly thickens so it's getting close
here so just keep stirring keeping an
eye on it and what we're looking for
isn't a super thick mixture it's
basically going to be thick enough to
coat the back of a spoon which is what
we have right about here so that's
looking good at
that point we're going to go ahead and
dump in our lobster meat and basically
as soon as that Lobster is heated
through you're ready to serve and by the
way it's easy to make a great lobster
Newburg and it's easy to film a lobster
Newburg but it's not easy to film a
great lobster Newburg okay because I'm
trying to get different shots and
changed camera positions I kind of had a
start and stop this a few times and you
know what it kind of sounds like I'm
complaining now so I'm going to stop so
bottom line this is going to be way
easier for you than it was for me so
like I said we'll just keep mixing that
and when we think that Lobster is heated
through we're ready for the final steps
which is just a little seasoning so I'm
gonna go ahead and stir in a little salt
to taste and then right before I spoon
this up I do like to add a little bit of
fresh herb this time I'm using a little
bit of Italian parsley but fresh
tarragon is beautiful in this you could
also use chervil if you want also very
nice but that's up to you you are the
wind berg of your Newburgh so put what
you like and as soon as that's stirred
in we're ready to eat and this is most
commonly served over buttered toast but
we're going to fancy it up a little bit
and serve it in these gorgeous puff
pastry shells which you can't buy
anywhere you're gonna have to make those
yourself
luckily I'm going to show you that
technique in the next video very simple
to do if you know the tricks but anyway
whether used in puff pastry or butter
toast you're gonna spoon that over and
of course we're also going to want a
generous amount of that sherry cream
sauce and regarding the sauce color I
kind of like the natural look if you've
seen Newberg's before and they were
white that's because they were done with
the white wine and then you also see
versions that are red or orange where
people have added tomato I guess to make
the sauce look more lobstery but I do
like the natural look and once that
shells been filled we'll pop on the top
and that lobster Newburg is done I mean
look at that you would totally eat that
would you but anyway time to go in for
the official taste we go ahead start
with a little bit of that lobster meat
and because we cook a lobster ourselves
and did not overcook it it's sweet and
tender but this is not the kind of dish
you want to eat the components
separately let's cut right in and this
is definitely a fork and knife er I've
never had much luck cutting puff pastry
with just a fork and as good as that
Lobster was on its own when you combine
that with that crispy buttery puff
pastry which is all drenched and drippin
with that amazing sauce we are talking
about a world-class bite of food oh and
by the way if you ever happen to share a
recipe with a friend and owns a
restaurant I would try to get him to
sign something that prevents them from
changing the name if you ever have a
falling out hey you never know you don't
want to end up getting anagram
but anyway I really do hope you give
